comments:
This course includes the major topics of cell biology and microbiology that are
foundational for an understanding of normal and pathological cellular processes. Topics
include the study of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell structures and functions, the main
biological molecules, membrane transport, cellular communications, the flow of genetic
information, cell division, and cellular metabolism. The context for this course is the
application of cell biology to understanding the cellular basis of human diseases and the
role of genetics and genomics in health and disease processes.
Students found this class challenging, covering a lot of information in a short
amount of time. Several students remarked that the course was particularly difficult at
first but became more manageable. Apart from the difficulty, students commented on the
"very interesting" material and "background knowledge" it provided for later courses.
Students found Professor Wislowski helpful, yet challenging. One student noted
grading inconsistencies and difficult testing style.
Many students found the class difficult due to its "fast pace" and "very detailed"
readings. Some felt that a strong background in biology was necessary in order to do well
in the class.

This course includes the major topics of cell biology and microbiology that are
foundational for an understanding of normal and pathological cellular processes. Topics
include the study of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell structures and functions, the main
biological molecules, membrane transport, cellular communications, the flow of genetic
information, cell division, and cellular metabolism. The context for this course is the
application of cell biology to understanding the cellular basis of human diseases and the
role of genetics and genomics in health and disease processes. The course centers on
various case studies to present the material.
Overall students felt they learned a great deal of material over the course of the
semester. Students commented that the material covered was extremely thorough, delving
into a great depth of biological topics. Both students who had not taken biology in years
and those that had recently taken AP Biology felt they left the class having learned a
great deal. This course is a bit unconventional due to the large faculty instructing
students. Some students found the breadth of instruction overwhelming, and
“inconsistent.”
Many students took this course as their first science-oriented nursing class and
were surprised at how quickly they were immersed straight into such difficult and
detailed material. Many were concerned or felt disadvantaged by not having taken
biology for a few years and were overwhelmed with the amount of material that was
covered. In fact, most students felt that there was too much material to be covered
comfortably over the course of the semester. Readings were described as “very detailed”
and required great concentration. Overall, many found the course rewarding. Students
noted that hard work was required; individuals had to remain constantly working on
assignments, readings, and actively engaged in the class. Regardless of the course’s rigor,
students felt it was a good basis for the rest of their science courses.
